name: viola
definition: A stringed instrument of the violin family, slightly larger than a violin, tuned a fifth lower, and having a deeper, more sonorous tone.
description:
The viola is a bowed and plucked string instrument which is similar to the violin and cello.

It is slightly larger than a violin in size and has a lower and deeper sound than a violin.

The viola's sound is described as more dark, earthy, or mellow than the violin's sound.

The viola is played with a bow in the right hand. Playing with the bow is called arco. Sometimes the strings may be plucked - technique called pizzicato.

The viola often plays the inner voices in string quartets and symphonic writing, and it is more likely than the first violin to play accompaniment parts.

Music that is written for the viola differs from that of most other instruments, in that it primarily uses the alto clef, which is otherwise rarely used.

The viola is found in chamber ensembles of string instruments only, and also in full symphony orchestras where strings, woodwinds, brass, and percussion instruments play together.

facts.name: Five centimetres longer than violin
facts.value: It is built in proportions similar to those of the violin but has a body length of 37 to 43 cm, about 5 cm longer than a violin.

facts.name: Initially used to double cello parts
facts.value: In the 18th-century orchestra the viola usually doubled cello parts. Christoph Willibald Gluck, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, and Joseph Haydn gave it distinctive treatment, and it gradually assumed an independent orchestral role.

facts.name: Sometimes confused with violin
facts.value: When people see the viola, sometimes they think it is a violin. This is because the viola is only a little larger than a violin, and like the violin, the viola is held on the player's left shoulder.

facts.name: Darker colour
facts.value: The viola is usually a darker colour, such as Acorn Attack or Dark Dreaming.

facts.name: Part of strings quartet
facts.value: It is one of the main instruments in a strings quartet, along with two violins and a cello.

facts.name: Luthier
facts.value: The person that makes and repairs violas is called a luthier.

facts.name: Cinderella of the orchestra
facts.value: The viola is also known as the Cinderella of the orchestra.

facts.name: Found its way in the folk music
facts.value: Although not as commonly used as the violin in folk music, the viola is nevertheless used by many folk musicians across the world.

facts.name: Different sound from violin
facts.value: Even though the viola and violin can play many of the same notes, they each have a special sound quality.

facts.name: Lower than violin but higher than cello
facts.value: The viola sounds lower than a violin, but higher than a cello.

related.definition: A stringed instrument played with a bow, having four strings, an unfretted fingerboard and a shallow body, and capable of great flexibility in range, tone, and dynamics.
A four-stringed musical instrument of the violin family, pitched lower than the viola but higher than the double bass.
The largest bowed stringed instrument in the modern orchestra, also used frequently in jazz ensembles, especially played pizzicato.
